title: (x) Diamond dots on 'i's - various {gang}
content:
Hi Folks,   
   
I'm looking for instances of where lower case " i " is earmarked by "diamonds." It can be serif / sans/ decorative, etc.   
   
I am aware of Granby, Cable, Kable, and some cuts of Goudy.   
   
ANY help would be (and is ) GREATLY appreciated. Blessings, geo.
author: george_scombulis

comments.content: Emigre's beautiful [Priori](http://web.archive.org/web/20050516225239/http:/www.emigre.com/EF.php?fid=197) has them in both serif and sans.

A number of Venetian revivals, including [Jenson Classico](http://web.archive.org/web/20050516225239/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/linotype/jenson-classico/?PREFS_SET%5BRenderSize%5D=72&PREFS_SET%5BRenderString%5D=i), [Iowan Old Style](http://web.archive.org/web/20050516225239/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/bitstream/iowan-old-style/).   
   
Some of the Old English fonts, like [Collins](http://web.archive.org/web/20050516225239/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/scriptorium/collins-old-english/). [Hefeweizen](http://web.archive.org/web/20050516225239/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/thometz/hefeweizen/). [Generation Uncial](http://web.archive.org/web/20050516225239/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/abctypes/generation-uncial/). [ITC Korigan](http://web.archive.org/web/20050516225239/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/abctypes/generation-uncial/) (ok, so it's a kinda squashy diamond). [Jester](http://web.archive.org/web/20050516225239/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/drewfonts/jester/).   
   
 [ITC Zapf Chancery](http://web.archive.org/web/20050516225239/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/linotype/itc-zapf-chancery/). [Clairvaux](http://web.archive.org/web/20050516225239/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/linotype/clairvaux/). Our very own Hrant's [Cristaal](http://web.archive.org/web/20050516225239/http:/www.themicrofoundry.com/f_cristaal.html).   
   
A few more lineales, probably inspired by Kabel: [Fedra Sans](http://web.archive.org/web/20050516225239/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/typotheque/fedra-sans/) (and [Fedra Mono](http://web.archive.org/web/20050516225239/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/typotheque/fedra-mono/) and [Serif](http://web.archive.org/web/20050516225239/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/typotheque/fedra-serif-a/)). [Albe Sans](http://web.archive.org/web/20050516225239/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/bergsland/albe-sans/).   
   
Hope this helps.

[Ondine](http://web.archive.org/web/20050516225239/http:/www.myfonts.com/search?PREFS_SET%5BRenderSize%5D=72&PREFS_SET%5BRenderString%5D=Uncial&search%5Btext%5D=ondine) and many other [uncials](http://web.archive.org/web/20050516225239/http:/www.myfonts.com/search?PREFS_SET%5BRenderSize%5D=72&PREFS_SET%5BRenderString%5D=Uncial&search%5Btext%5D=uncial&itemsperpage=65&resultcount=65&page=1) (you'll have to scroll a bit to find them.)

As any Londoner must surely notice on a daily basis, Johnston's [Underground](http://web.archive.org/web/20050516225239/http:/www.p22.com/products/london.html) lettering has such an �i�.   
   
(Of course what we really see is New Johnston, which is much more thoroughgoing in its use of the diamond motif. Those who enjoy reading other people's style guides -- surely I'm not the only one? -- will find much to entertain them [here](http://web.archive.org/web/20050516225239/http:/www.tfl.gov.uk/tfl/about/corp-design/standards-underground.shtml).)

Call off the hounds !   
 I wish I could send you all a little something from Tiffany's, instead I can only offer heartfelt thoughts of gratitude to all of you whom have assisted in my search. Big hugs and, again, thank you one and all. Geo.
Well considering the title of this thread, I expected at least a small diamond by way of thanks.
